Comments_Questions: How clearly did the instructor define the topic of study
How clearly did the instructor outline the expectation for the course, classroom activity and homework
How well were individual class sessions prepared and presented
How well did lectures fit within the boundaries of the course
How available was the instructor for help outside the classroom
How useful were assignments in furthering an understanding of the topic
If tests were given, how fairly did they measure knowledge gained?
How useful was this course in preparing you for production work
How would you evaluate the instructor's knowledge of the material
Please offer additional comments on such topics as: what worked best about the course, suggested improvements, class materials, etc.
Comments_List: I liked that Ben's always taught with the end goal in mind.
It took me a while to get over my insecurities concerning math but looking back I feel a great relief and understand where we came from and where we are headed with the class.
We talk about it in class, we do the homework.  Pretty straightforward.
Ben outlined these things clearly and directly early on.
Sessions in which we went beyond the textbook material were most effective in furthering my understanding of the material.
All class sessions were prepared and executed well.
It's a lot of work.  I understand why we have that much homework, but it is often difficult to balance Structures homework with production assignments.
The workload was appropriate. Some Lectures were easier than others -  such is life.
I didnt seek him out, but Ben seemed very available for those who did.
The homework is absolutely vital, and it gave the opportunity for practice that we need for this type of class.
I appreciated that the tests generally had questions that were similar to problems that we will encounter on production assignments.

I feel like I understand which concepts I need to apply to my production work, but found it difficult to filter through all of the other information that is negligible when doing the calculations.  As we get further into the class, I think it would help to dissect problems that have come up in production work as a class so that we can see the thought process.  We did this once (we were talking about the deck in El Huracan, I think), and it was easily the most thought-provoking and engaging day in class all semester.
After the first section, I feel I'm not sure how to apply the stuff I've learned to actual production work.

I think this will come as we continue on to more complicated material, but I dont currently feel confident in how to generalize the textbook examples to what Im actually building - I can answer a specific question but dont always know how to apply that knowledge to a scenic design.

Even though I see the theoretical application of the knowledge and understanding I gained, because I have yet to experience production work in which I can translate that knowledge into a real application. This is not a fault of the class just a personal coincidence. Nonetheless I can see myself applying what I learned.
Ben obviously knows his stuff, but I think sometimes he rushes past concepts and processes that could use a little more attention.
Ben is extremely experienced and knows his field well, no doubt about it.

I think it would help to do examples in class that are similar to the ones in the book but aren't exactly the ones in the book.  It would certainly take more time to slowly walk through the problem, but it would give us a chance to think through the problem as a group and find places where we or our classmates tend to make mistakes.

An updated answer key for the even problems would help immensely.  There were several times where I would get an answer different from the back of the book and spend a significant amount of time trying to figure out what I'd done wrong, only to discover that I hadn't done anything wrong at all, and the book hadn't been updated to the new numbers, or contained a typo.  It would be relatively easy to have someone type up the changes and hand them out at the beginning of the semester.

It would be nice if the syllabus indicated the resources available to students, e.g. for folks with a learning disability, as the other syllabi do - I know the information is readily available in other locations, but having it on the syllabus is an easier starting point if a student does need to have a conversation with a professor about any accommodations.
I think Ben at times overestimates my/our experience in the field. I have yet to gain the proficiency I think he sometimes relies on in his questioning.
